page.title: Ain't No Rest for the Wicked

revision.text:
{{Infobox song | name = Ain't No Rest for the Wicked | cover = ain't no rest for the wicked.jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Cage the Elephant]] | album = [[Cage the Elephant (album)|Cage the Elephant]] | released = June 16, 2008 | format = [[CD single]], [[7" Vinyl]] | recorded = | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Alternative rock]], [[cowpunk]], [[punk blues]] | length = 2:52 | label = [[Relentless Records|Relentless]] | writer = [[Jared Champion]], Lincoln Parish, Brad Shultz, [[Matt Shultz (singer)|Matt Schultz]], Daniel Tichenor | producer = [[Jay Joyce]] | prev_title = [[In One Ear (song)|In One Ear]] | prev_year = 2008 | next_title = [[Back Against the Wall (song)|Back Against the Wall]] | next_year = 2009 | misc = {{Extra music sample |filename=Ain't No Rest for the Wicked.ogg|title="Ain't No Rest for the Wicked" |Type=Single|format=[[Ogg]]}} }} "'''Ain't No Rest for the Wicked'''" is the third [[single (music)|single]] by the American [[rock music|rock]] band [[Cage the Elephant]]. It was released as a [[CD single]] on June 16, 2008 by [[Relentless Records]] and became the first Top 40 hit for the band in the UK. A music video was filmed for this song which was directed by D.A.R.Y.L of Pulse Films. A later re-release in North America the following year reached number 92 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], reached number 3 on the [[Alternative Songs]] chart and number 8 on the [[Mainstream Rock Tracks]] chart. ==Composition== The song talks about three particular instances in which the narrator realizes "there ain't no rest for the wicked." First, he encounters a [[prostitute]] asking if he desires to spend the night with her. The narrator proceeds to ask her why she does what she does. The chorus (her response) analyzes the main reasons why individuals follow the paths they follow ("...Money don't grow on trees, I've got bills to pay, I've got mouths to feed..."). The narrator, fifteen minutes later, is mugged by a criminal, whom he asks the same question and from whom he receives the same answer. Finally, upon turning on the television, the narrator sees a preacher being arrested for stealing the funds of his church. This is followed by a third chorus saying that everyone is the same and we all have no rest "until we close our eyes for good." Lead singer Matt Shultz stated the song was inspired by an old co-worker of his who at the time was a drug dealer. When Shultz asked him why he dealt drugs, the co-worker told him that "There's no rest for the wicked." Shultz was a plumber at the time, and said that he wrote the lyrics on a piece of drywall which he found while working at his co-worker's house.{{cite web|last=Lopez|first=Korina|title=On the verge: Cage the Elephant stampedes to fame|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/music/news/2010-07-27-cageOTV27_ST_N.htm|publisher=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=28 April 2012|date=22 April 2011}} ==Usage in media== The song appeared in a commercial for the TNT series ''[[Leverage (TV series)|Leverage]]''; in the 2010 film ''[[The Bounty Hunter (2010 film)|The Bounty Hunter]]''; in an episode of ''[[The Vampire Diaries]]'' ("Isobel"); in a third-season episode of ''[[Jersey Shore (TV series)|Jersey Shore]]''; as the opening song of Canadian reality television series ''[[Yukon Gold (TV series)|Yukon Gold]]''; and for the opening sequence of the 2009 video game ''[[Borderlands (video game)|Borderlands]]''. It is also mentioned in ''[[Borderlands 2]]''. Cage the Elephant performed the song on national television on the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]''. In the pilot episode for FOX's ''[[Lucifer (TV series)|Lucifer]]'', the song is in both the opening and closing scenes of the episode. It was also used in the Netflix series, ''[[13 Reasons Why]]''. Also used in [[Hawaii Five-0 (2010 TV series)|Hawaii Five-0]], Season 8, episode 1: ''A'ole e 'olelo mai ana ke ahi ua ana ia.''{{Citation|title=[["Hawaii Five-0" A'ole e 'olelo mai ana ke ahi ua ana ia (TV Episode 2017)|url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt6687112/soundtrack|access-date=2018-10-02}} == Track listings== # "Ain't No Rest for the Wicked" – 2:52 # "Ain't No Rest for the Wicked" (Acoustic Version) – 3:02 ==Chart positions== ===Weekly charts=== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" ! Chart (2008–09) ! Peak
position |- {{singlechart|Billboardcanadianhot100|42|artist=Cage the Elephant|accessdate=January 8, 2015|rowheader=true}} |- {{singlechart|Billboardjapanhot100|90|artist=Cage the Elephant|accessdate=January 8, 2015|rowheader=true}} |- {{singlechart|UKsinglesbyname|32|artist=Cage the Elephant|accessdate=January 8, 2015|rowheader=true}} |- {{singlechart|Billboardhot100|83|artist=Cage the Elephant|accessdate=January 8, 2015|rowheader=true}} |- {{singlechart|Billboardadultalternativesongs|24|artist=Cage the Elephant|accessdate=January 8, 2015|rowheader=true}} |- {{singlechart|Billboardalternativesongs|3|artist=Cage the Elephant|accessdate=January 8, 2015|rowheader=true}} |- {{singlechart|Billboardrocksongs|6|artist=Cage the Elephant|accessdate=January 8, 2015|rowheader=true}} |- {{singlechart|Billboardmainstreamrock|8|artist=Cage the Elephant|accessdate=January 8, 2015|rowheader=true}} |- |} ===Year-end charts=== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" |- ! scope="col"| Chart (2009) ! scope="col"| Position |- ! scope="row"| US Alternative Songs (''Billboard''){{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/year-end/2009/alternative-songs|title=Alternative Songs – Year-End 2009|work=Billboard|accessdate=September 6, 2018}} | 7 |- ! scope="row"| US Hot Rock Songs (''Billboard''){{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/year-end/2009/hot-rock-songs|title=Hot Rock Songs – Year-End 2009|work=Billboard|accessdate=September 6, 2018}} | 13 |} ==Certifications== {{Certification Table Top}} {{Certification Table Entry|region=United States|title=Ain't No Rest for the Wicked|artist=Cage the Elephant|type=single|award=Platinum|relyear=2008|certyear=2011|refname="RIAA"}} {{Certification Table Bottom|nounspecified=true}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{youtube|HKtsdZs9LJo|"Ain't No Rest for the Wicked" Official music video}} {{Cage the Elephant}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ain't No Rest For The Wicked}} [[Category:2008 singles]] [[Category:Cage the Elephant songs]] [[Category:Songs about prostitutes]] [[Category:Songs critical of religion]] [[Category:Song recordings produced by Jay Joyce]] [[Category:Relentless Records singles]] [[Category:2008 songs]] [[Category:Songs written by Matt Shultz (singer)]]

[[File:Al-miraj and Serpent.png|thumb|464x464px|Page depicting an Al-Miraj with a serpent, most likely from the tale of Alexander the Great defeating the serpent and receiving the Al-Miraj as a gift. From page 131 of the Bavarian Manuscript.<ref name=":0" />]] {{For|the Night Journey of the Islamic prophet Muhammad|Isra and Mi'raj}} '''Al-mi'raj''' or '''Almiraj''' ([[Arabic]]: المعراج ''al-mi'raj'') is a mythical beast said to live on a mysterious island called Jezîrat al-Tennyn (Sea-Serpent Island) within the confines of the [[Indian Ocean]]. According to legend, the beast was a gift given to Alexander the Great from the inhabitants of the island after he killed a large dragon that had been eating the livestock of the people there.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.rhinoresourcecenter.com/pdf_files/131/1311808615.pdf?view|title=Studies in Muslim Iconography I. The Unicorn|last=Ettinghausen|first=Richard|publisher=Washington, D.C. Smithsonian|year=1950|isbn=9781258518929|location=|pages=66-67}}</ref> It is mentioned in [[Zakariya al-Qazwini|Zakariya Ib Muhammad Al-Qazwini's]] ''[[ʿAjā'ib al-makhlūqāt wa gharā'ib al-mawjūdāt|Marvels of Things Created and Miraculous Aspects of Things Existing]]'' (often times shortened to ''The Wonders of Creation'').<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://www.wdl.org/en/item/8962/|title=The Wonders of Creation|last=Qazwini|first=Zakariya Ibn Muhammad|publisher=|year=1260-1280|isbn=|location=|pages=131}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=http://art.thewalters.org/detail/84067/dragon-of-tannin-island-and-horned-rabit/|title=The Wonder's of Creation (Walter's Manuscript)|last=Qazwini|first=Zakariya Ibn Muhammad|last2=Nathani|first2=Muhammad Ibn Muhammad Shakir Ruzmah-i (Scribe)|publisher=|year=Ottoman Empire|isbn=|location=Turkey|pages=}}</ref> [[File:Al-Miraj and Serpent from Walters Manuscript.png|thumb|272x272px|From the Walters Manuscript - Walters Museum of Art Baltimore, MD <ref name=":1" /> ]]
==Pop culture references== Al-Mi'raj has been occasionally featured in video and role-playing games.
*[[Al-mi'raj (Dungeons & Dragons)|Al-Mi'raj has been adapted]] into ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'', as part of the 1st edition Advanced Dungeons and Dragons [[Fiend Folio]]. *An enemy in the ''[[Dragon Quest]]'' series (アルミラージ ... arumirāji), first appearing in ''[[Dragon Quest III]]'', where it is a low-level monster with a sleep attack used to render players helpless while it attacks. In U.S. localizations it has usually been renamed to "Spiked Hare", but its name is preserved in the Game Boy Color version <ref>[http://www.woodus.com/den/games/dw3gbc/monsters.php Dragon Warrior 3 Monster List]]</ref> Unlike the normal legendary Miraj, this Mi'raj is purple with a white horn and white cheeks. Its standard treasure is eight gold and a Leather Hat. In ''[[Dragon Quest VIII]]'', it carries Medicinal Herbs and Bunny Tails.<ref>[http://www.woodus.com/den/games/dq8ps2/monsters.php Dragon Quest 3 Monster List]</ref> *In Episode 10 of the anime ''[[Is It Wrong to Try to Pick Up Girls in a Dungeon?]]'' the first floor of the mid level contains multiple white rabbits that walk on two legs. Two of the main characters Lilly and Welf claim that they are the protagonist Bell Cranel due to the matching red eyes and white hair the rabbits are then identified as al-mi'raj by Bell before being interrupted as the rabbits attack. * In the animated short "Red" (2010) the little wolf-boy protects Red from an Al-Mir'aj that can grow to a monstrous size, and kills it. * The ''[[Yu-Gi-Oh]]'' Breakers of Shadow booster pack has released a card based on this mythical creature called Al-Lumi'raj. * The game ''Rage of Bahamut'' (and subsequently the Shadowverse CCG, which is based on it) contains a character called Moon Al-Mir'aj, a humanoid rabbit with a black horn called Ramina. *In the [[Donald Duck]] story "[[Mythological Menagerie]]", written and drawn by Don Rosa, Donald tries to fool Huey, Dewey and Louie by painting a rabbit yellow and attaching a horn to it, but the nephews identify it as a Mi'Raj. *In [[Brave Frontier]], Al-mi'raj is a common light-element unit, depicted as a white rabbit with tufts of blue fur and a golden horn.
[[Image:Ancient Al-Mir'aj depiction.jpg|thumb|right|300px|An Al-Mir'aj from '''Marvels of Things Created and Miraculous Aspects of Things Existing''' by Zakariya Ibn Muhammad al-Qazwini (1203-1283 AD){{cn|date=June 2018}}]]
== See also == *[[Jackalope]] *[[Lepus cornutus]] *[[Wolpertinger]] *[[Shope papilloma virus]]

page.title: American Society for the Defense of Tradition, Family and Property

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
{{see also|Tradition, Family and Property}} {{primary sources|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox non-profit | name = American Society for the Defense of Tradition, Family, and Property (TFP) | image = TFP Standard.png | caption = Rampant lion on a red standard, logo of the American TFP | type = [[501(c)(3)]] [[Charitable organization|Charity]] | tax_id = | registration_id = 23-7325778 ([[Employer Identification Number|EIN]]) | founded_date = {{Start date|1973}} | location = Spring Grove, Pennsylvania | key_people = Raymond E. Drake, President
John Horvat II, Vice-President | area_served = United States | revenue = $8,530,115 (FY 2012)[http://www.charitynavigator.org/index.cfm?bay=search.summary&orgid=6863 "American Society for the Defense of Tradition, Family and Property", Charity Navigator] | num_volunteers = 75 | num_employees = 60 | homepage = {{URL|http://www.tfp.org/}} }} The '''American Society for the Defense of Tradition, Family and Property''' (TFP), or "The American TFP," is a special campaign of The Foundation for a [[Christian Civilization]], Inc. ("FCC").[http://www.tfpstudentaction.org/fundraising-disclosure-notice.html "Fundraising Disclosure Notice", TFP Student Action] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110103140842/http://www.tfpstudentaction.org/fundraising-disclosure-notice.html |date=2011-01-03 }} It is one of a number of autonomous national TFPs which claims to form "the world's largest anticommunist and antisocialist network of Catholic inspiration."{{citation | title = The American TFP | journal = Crusade Magazine | publisher = The American Society for the Defense of Tradition, Family and Property | place = Hanover, PA | volume = 65 | issue = | date = September–October 2003 | page = [1] | url = http://www.tfp.org/magazines/crusade_mag_vol_65.pdf }} ==History== Founded in 1973, it is one of many "[[Tradition, Family and Property]]" groups (TFPs) and like-minded organizations worldwide, all of which are inspired by the work of the Brazilian intellectual, politician and activist [[Plinio Corrêa de Oliveira]]. The first American group was incorporated in 1975, and established its first [[Hermitage (religious retreat)|hermitage]] in 1977 in Yonkers, New York. The Yonkers location was subsequently closed, with the hermits establishing their permanent hermitage on 70 acres in Spring Grove, Pennsylvania.[http://www.oblon.com/sites/default/files/ttab/2009/91157073.pdf "Mary Queen of the Third Millennium, Inc. v. The Foundation for a Christian Civilization, Inc.", United States Patent And Trademark Office, December 3, 2008]{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The Foundation for a Christian Civilization ("Foundation") was incorporated in 1973, drawing on earlier ties between Brazilians, who traveled to the US to develop a North American affiliate. The American TFP developed early connections with leaders of the [[New Right#United States|religious and political right]], including Paul Weyrich of the [[Heritage Foundation]] and the Free Congress Foundation and [[Morton Blackwell]] of the [[College Republican National Committee]] and the Reagan administration.{{Citation | last = Power | first = Margaret | author-link = | editor-last = Durham | editor-first = Martin | editor2-last = Power | editor2-first = Margaret | editor-link = | editor2-link = | date = 2011 | title = New Perspectives on the Transnational Right | chapter = Transnational, Conservative, Catholic, and Anti-Communist: Tradition, Family, and Property (TFP) | publisher = Palgrave-MacMillan | place = New York | pages = 96–97 | isbn = 978-0-230-62370-5 }}{{Citation | last = Lernoux | first = Penny | author-link = Penny Lernoux | title = People of God: The Struggle for World Catholicism | place = New York | publisher = Viking | year = 1989 | page = 343 | isbn = 0-670-81529-2 }} Founded to help fundraising for a Catholic counterrevolution against communism, it subsequently becoming a civil cultural organization that aims to uphold and promote the values of Christian civilization. The Foundation later merged in June 1992 with American TFP to form a single corporation identified as The Foundation for a Christian Civilization. Following the death of the founder in 1995, the American TFP split away from the original ideals of the [http://www.tfp.org.br Brazilian TFP]. ==Organization== The American TFP is staffed by approximately 75 full-time members and employees. It claims, with its affiliated [[America Needs Fatima]] campaign, to have more than 120,000 members nationwide. The organization's national headquarters are in Spring Grove, Pennsylvania, with regional offices in Chicago, Illinois; McLean, Virginia; Lafayette, Louisiana; Orange County, California; Hazleton, Pennsylvania; and Rossville, Kansas. The organization solicits funds as a non-profit charity, not as a diocesan organization."[http://www.miamiarch.org/atimo_s/Bulletin/2007/Bulletin20071017.pdf "Office of the Chancellor", ''Pastoral Bulletin'', Archdiocese of Miami, October 17, 2007] Its annual public reports to the [[Internal Revenue Service]] indicate that between 2002 and 2014 it dispersed $1,800,000 to support the St. Louis de Montfort Academy and $1,500,000 to support related organizations in North and South America, most significantly Canada Needs Our Lady, Associação dos Fundadores and the ''Tradición y Acción'' organizations of Colombia and Peru.{{Citation | authors = The Foundation for a Christian Civilization, Inc. (Doing business as The American TFP; America Needs Fatima) | year = | title = Return of Organization Exempt From Income Tax (IRS Form 990N) | publisher = Foundation Center | publication-place = New York | page = | pages = | name-list-format=vanc | postscript = ,}} [http://990s.foundationcenter.org/990_pdf_archive/237/237325778/237325778_200306_990.pdf 2002] [http://990s.foundationcenter.org/990_pdf_archive/237/237325778/237325778_200406_990.pdf 2003] [http://990s.foundationcenter.org/990_pdf_archive/237/237325778/237325778_200506_990.pdf 2004] [http://990s.foundationcenter.org/990_pdf_archive/237/237325778/237325778_200606_990.pdf 2005] [http://990s.foundationcenter.org/990_pdf_archive/237/237325778/237325778_200706_990.pdf 2006] [http://990s.foundationcenter.org/990_pdf_archive/237/237325778/237325778_200806_990.pdf 2007] [http://990s.foundationcenter.org/990_pdf_archive/237/237325778/237325778_200906_990.pdf 2008] [http://990s.foundationcenter.org/990_pdf_archive/237/237325778/237325778_201006_990.pdf 2009] [http://990s.foundationcenter.org/990_pdf_archive/237/237325778/237325778_201106_990.pdf 2010] [http://990s.foundationcenter.org/990_pdf_archive/237/237325778/237325778_201206_990.pdf 2011] [http://990s.foundationcenter.org/990_pdf_archive/237/237325778/237325778_201306_990.pdf 2012] [http://990s.foundationcenter.org/990_pdf_archive/237/237325778/237325778_201406_990.pdf 2013]. Retrieved 25 April 2015 ==Worldview== {{third-party|section|date=February 2015}} The American TFP's worldview is based on Oliveira's 1959 essay, ''Revolution and Counter-Revolution''. According to the aims laid out in this book, TFP acts to oppose what Oliveira believed was an anti-Christian process that had undermined Christian civilization since the 14th century, the "Revolution" of the study's title. Oliveira considered that this "Revolution" had three phases which progressively undermined the Church and social order: # The Protestant "Pseudo-Reformation" and its rejection of religious authority and inequality, in particular the Pope. # The "Enlightenment" and the French Revolution and its rejection of temporal authority, in particular the King and nobility. # The Communist Revolution and its rejection of economic inequality; the final phases seek to eradicate the Church and Christian civilization while applying more [[radical egalitarianism]] and implementing neo-paganism. The American TFP promotes what it sees as the values of Christianity, and opposes [[Liberalism|liberal]] and [[egalitarianism|egalitarian]] ideas, policies, and trends in both society as a whole and in the Catholic Church. While supporting selected elements of Catholic teaching, the group also argues for the need for authentic elites in society that raise, above all, the moral tone of general society, as witnessed by Oliveira's ''Nobility & Analogous Traditional Elites in the Allocutions of Pius XII''. In this book, Oliveira seeks to counter the "[[preferential option for the poor]]" found in [[Catholic social teaching]] and in [[Liberation theology]], with support for the natural elite that exists in all societies, following the teaching of Pius XII, that they may become the obligated class working for the good of society (Noblesse Oblige). {{quote|If the Revolution is disorder, the Counter-Revolution is the restoration of order. And by order we understand the peace of Christ in the reign of Christ. That is, Christian civilization, austere and hierarchical, fundamentally sacral, anti-egalitarian and anti-liberal.}} According to some commenters, including [[traditionalist Catholic]] sources, TFP claims "to move from Christian principles, but they tend to move in the political arena".{{Citation | title = A 'Phenomenon' Called TFP | newspaper = New York Times | page = WC7 | date = December 17, 1978 }} Ardently anti-Communist, the group's interpretation of Catholic teaching led it to voice its opposition to the Vatican's policy of rapprochement with Communism.[http://www.tfp.org/tfp-home/statements/the-church-and-the-communist-state-the-impossible-coexistence.html "The Church and the Communist State: The Impossible Coexistence"] ==Activities== {{third-party|section|date=January 2015}} The American TFP actively promotes its views through newspaper advertisements, direct mail, leafleting, public meetings, and 'caravans', groups of volunteers that spread TFP's message to the public at large. Its campaigns cover a wide range of issues, including the [[Roman Catholic Church sex abuse scandal|sexual abuse scandals in the Catholic Church]],[http://www.tfp.org/current-campaigns/the-church-shall-prevail/ The Church Shall Prevail Campaign Central] [[Islam]] and [[9/11]],{{Cite web |url=http://www.tfp.org/current-campaigns/2001/tfp-analyzes-a-psywar-against-order.html |title=A Psywar Against Order |access-date=2009-12-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604115033/http://www.tfp.org/current-campaigns/2001/tfp-analyzes-a-psywar-against-order.html |archive-date=2011-06-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }} [[just war]],[http://www.tfp.org/tfp-home/books-and-statements-online/just-war-and-the-pacifist-offensive-on-sovereignty.html Just War and the Pacifist Offensive Against Sovereignty] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101202080348/http://www.tfp.org/tfp-home/books-and-statements-online/just-war-and-the-pacifist-offensive-on-sovereignty.html |date=2010-12-02 }} [[abortion]],[http://www.tfp.org/current-campaigns/in-defense-of-the-unborn/ In Defense of the Unborn Campaign Central] [[euthanasia]],[http://www.tfp.org/current-campaigns/2005/a-plea-for-terri.html A Plea for Terri] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604115334/http://www.tfp.org/current-campaigns/2005/a-plea-for-terri.html |date=2011-06-04 }} embryonic [[stem cell research]],{{Cite web |url=http://www.tfp.org/current-campaigns/in-defense-of-the-unborn/demolishing-myths-about-stem-cell-research.html |title=Demolishing Myths About Stem Cell Research |access-date=2009-12-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604115346/http://www.tfp.org/current-campaigns/in-defense-of-the-unborn/demolishing-myths-about-stem-cell-research.html |archive-date=2011-06-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }} [[homosexuality]] and [[same-sex marriage]],[http://www.tfp.org/traditional-marriage-crusade.html Traditional Marriage Crusade Campaign Central] and [[Sexual orientation and military service|homosexuals in the military]]. In addition, TFP also supports [[creation science]] and [[intelligent design]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tfp.org/tfp-home/fighting-for-our-culture/why-cant-evolution-evolve.html|title=Why Can't Evolution Evolve?|date=3 May 2012|publisher=The American Society for the Defense of Tradition, Family and Property|accessdate=13 January 2013|quote=If there is a side to the debate where things are changing, it is that of those favoring creation. These advocates have gone way beyond Genesis and present scientific arguments to justify their positions. Their positions are not frozen in the unverifiable past but use every possible field of modern science to support their positions.}} The group also protests against films and plays that it views as [[blasphemy|blasphemous]], including [[Jean-Luc Godard]]'s 1985 film ''Hail Mary'', [[Martin Scorsese|Scorsese]]'s 1988 film ''[[The Last Temptation of Christ]]'', [[Terrence McNally|McNally]]'s 1998 play ''[[Corpus Christi (play)|Corpus Christi]]'', [[Kevin Smith]]'s 1999 film ''[[Dogma (film)|Dogma]]'', and [[Dan Brown]]'s ''[[The Da Vinci Code]]''. In October 1999, TFP local coordinators carried out 300 protests at movie theaters against ''Dogma'', and have mobilized 17,000 volunteers to hand out over 5 million protest fliers. The group has also been involved in other public and political actions, such as protesting the 2009 invitation to President [[Barack Obama]] to deliver the commencement address at the [[University of Notre Dame]].[http://www.tfp.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1197 "Notre Dame: How the Gold Dome Tarnished"] The president of TFP, Raymond E. Drake, wrote a letter to the president of Notre Dame, Fr. John Jenkins, concerning this issue, expressing "great perplexity and grief...that a priest of Holy Mother Church and president of one of America's most outstanding and emblematic Catholic universities would invite a manifestly pro-abortion president to give the commencement address and receive an honorary Doctor of Laws degree.[http://www.tfp.org/current-campaigns/2009/father-jenkins-urgently-reconsider.html Letter of the American TFP's president Raymond Drake to Fr. Jenkins] TFP has continued its ties with the political right as a participating sponsor of the [[Conservative Political Action Conference]]{{Citation | title = Rick Santorum to CPAC: "Let's Talk About How We Can Build a Great America Again" | publisher = [[American Conservative Union|The American Conservative Union]] | accessdate = March 6, 2015 | date = March 7, 2014 | url = http://conservative.org/rick-santorum-to-cpac-lets-talk-about-how-we-can-build-a-great-america-again/ | quote = Participating Sponsors: … Tradition, Family, Property… | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160111005324/http://conservative.org/rick-santorum-to-cpac-lets-talk-about-how-we-can-build-a-great-america-again/ | archive-date = 2016-01-11 | dead-url = yes | df = }} and by signing statements issued by the [[Heartland Institute]] that opposed housing finance reform legislation{{Citation | title = Free-Market Leaders Urge Senate to Reject Housing Finance Overhaul | publisher = [[Heartland Institute|The Heartland Institute]] | accessdate = March 6, 2015 | date = April 23, 2014 | url = http://news.heartland.org/newspaper-article/2014/04/23/free-market-leaders-urge-senate-reject-housing-finance-overhaul | quote = Coalition members include leaders from … Tradition, Family, Property, Inc.}} and discussions of [[climate change]] in comprehensive energy legislation{{Citation | title = [Open Letter to Senator Pete Domenici] | journal = Environment & Climate News | publisher = The Heartland Institute | volume = 6 | issue = 4 | page = 7 |date = May 2003| url = http://news.heartland.org/sites/all/modules/custom/heartland_migration/files/pdfs/12106.pdf }} and in the State Department funding authorization.{{Citation | title = [Open Letter to Congressman Henry Hyde] | journal = Environment & Climate News | publisher = The Heartland Institute | volume = 6 | issue = 6 | page = 15 |date = July 2003| url = http://news.heartland.org/sites/default/files/sites/all/modules/custom/heartland_migration/files/pdfs/12413.pdf }} TFP Student Action is the university campus outreach of the TFP.[http://www.tfpstudentaction.org TFP Student Action] Its activities include distributing fliers and other literature on the streets of universities, sponsoring speakers on campuses, hosting student conferences, and organizing protests and petitions, especially against the provision of information about abortion and the acceptance of LGBT students at Catholic universities. Its most recent campaign is against the 96 Catholic colleges and universities that allow LGBT student groups.[http://www.tfpstudentaction.org/get-involved/online-petitions/scandal-research-finds-homosexual-clubs-at-catholic-universities.html "Scandal: Research finds pro-homosexual clubs at 96 Catholic universities"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090907170630/http://www.tfpstudentaction.org/get-involved/online-petitions/scandal-research-finds-homosexual-clubs-at-catholic-universities.html |date=2009-09-07 }} In April 2009, volunteers of TFP Student Action traveled to the major cities of New Hampshire[http://www.nashuatelegraph.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20090415/NEWS01/304159911/-1/news "Gay marriage protesters make noise in Nashua"]{{dead link|date=September 2014}} and Maine[https://archive.is/20120719041655/http://www.bangordailynews.com/detail/104109.html Bloch, Jessica. "Protesters take aim at bill for gay marriage", ''Bangor Daily News'', April 18, 2009] to distribute literature against same-sex marriage. The American TFP provides the staff to run Saint Louis de Montfort Academy, a boys' [[boarding school]] in [[Herndon, Pennsylvania]], that provides students with a traditional [[Catholic education]].[http://www.montfortacademy.edu/ Saint Louis de Montfort Academy] It also operates Call to Chivalry summer camps, which express Oliveira's nostalgic medieval view{{Citation | last = Lernoux | first = Penny | author-link = Penny Lernoux | title = People of God: The Struggle for World Catholicism | place = New York | publisher = Viking | year = 1989 | page = 339 | isbn = 0-670-81529-2 }} of [[Nobility#European nobility|nobility]], [[Chivalry#Modern manifestations and revivals|chivalry]], and the imagined glory of the feudal past.{{Citation | last = Power | first = Margaret | author-link = | editor-last = Durham | editor-first = Martin | editor2-last = Power | editor2-first = Margaret | editor-link = | editor2-link = | date = 2011 | title = New Perspectives on the Transnational Right | chapter = Transnational, Conservative, Catholic, and Anti-Communist: Tradition, Family, and Property (TFP) | publisher = Palgrave-MacMillan | place = New York | page = 99 | isbn = 978-0-230-62370-5 }} ==Criticism for virulence == The American TFP has been cited in several article by the Southern Poverty Law Center (SPLC) for their anti-LGBTQ views{{Cite news|url=https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2011/10/07/extremists-many-stripes-gather-values-voter-summit-2011|title=Extremists of Many Stripes Gather at Values Voter Summit 2011|work=Southern Poverty Law Center|access-date=2018-07-23|language=en}}. According to the SPLC the TFP is a “virulently anti-LGBT group.”{{Cite news|url=https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2013/03/26/national-organization-marriage-has-rough-start-2013|title=National Organization for Marriage Has a Rough Start to 2013|work=Southern Poverty Law Center|access-date=2018-07-23|language=en}} ==See also== *[[America Needs Fatima]] *[[Alliance Defending Freedom]] *[[Catholic League (U.S.)|Catholic League]] *[[Christian Institute]] *[[Family Research Council]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.tfp.org/ American TFP Official Site] * [http://www.tfp.org/tfp-home/books-and-statements-online/revolution-and-counter-revolution.html Revolution and Counter-Revolution] (English; online links to both HTML and PDF formats) * [http://www.americaneedsfatima.org/ America Needs Fatima] * [http://www.tfpstudentaction.org/ TFP Student Action] * [http://www.montfortacademy.edu/ St. Louis de Montfort Academy] * [http://www.sos.wa.gov/charities/search_detail.aspx?charity_id=1695 "Foundation for a Christian Civilization, The", ''Charitable Solicitations Program Charity Profile Report'', Washington Secretary of State, Olympia, Washington] * [http://www.charitynavigator.org/index.cfm?bay=search.summary&orgid=6863#.VByV67l0zZ4 "American Society for the Defense of Tradition, Family and Property", Charity Navigator] {{DEFAULTSORT:American Society For The Defense Of Tradition, Family And Property}} [[Category:Traditionalist Catholicism]] [[Category:Anti-communist organizations in the United States]] [[Category:Intelligent design movement]] [[Category:Political advocacy groups in the United States]] [[Category:Catholic Church in the United States]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1973]] [[Category:1973 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:Anti–LGBT rights organizations in the United States]] [[Category:Catholic advocacy groups]] [[Category:Far-right politics in the United States]]

revision.text:
'''Bismillah ceremony''' is a cultural ceremony celebrated mostly by the indian subcontinent muslims. It is marking the start for a child in learning to recite the [[Qur'an]] in its Arabic script. It is not actually part of Islam . The ceremony marks how a child should read the [[Qur’an]] and say the prayers properly.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.thefridaytimes.com/31122010/page29.shtml|title= A Song of Hyderabad|author= Bilquis Jehan Khan|date= |work= |publisher= thefridaytimes.com|accessdate=28 January 2012}}</ref> The ceremony is named after the [[Basmala|''bismillah'']] ("In the name of [[Allah|God]]"), the beginning words in the Qur'an.
==The ceremony== It is held for both boys and girls between the age 4 and 5, sometimes when the child turns four years, four months and four days. The child is dressed in a traditional dress and jewelry and is made to recite the opening phrase of the Qur'ran, ''Bism illāh ir-raḥmān ir-raḥīm'' (In the name of Allah, the Compassionate, the Merciful) ([[786_(number)#In_religion|786]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://subknow.reonline.org.uk/node/125|title=Life & Death|author=|date=|work=|publisher=|accessdate=28 January 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120505234606/http://subknow.reonline.org.uk/node/125|archivedate=5 May 2012|df=}}</ref>
It is traditionally a grand evening affair with family and friends with lavish food served for dinner. Not only that but guests also exchange hugs and gifts
==See also== * [[Religious initiation rites]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Islamic culture]] [[Category:Indian culture]] [[Category:Ceremonies]] [[Category:Rites of passage]] [[Category:Islam in India]] [[Category:Islam in Pakistan]]

{{Infobox television | | show_name = Bridget Loves Bernie | image = Meredith Baxter David Birney Bridget Loves Bernie 1972.JPG | caption = The wedding photo. | runtime = 26 minutes | creator = [[Bernard Slade]] | starring = [[Meredith Baxter]]
[[David Birney]]
[[Audra Lindley]]
[[David Doyle (actor)|David Doyle]]
[[Harold J. Stone]]
[[Ned Glass]]
[[William Elliott (African American actor)|William Elliott]]
[[Bibi Osterwald]]
[[Robert Sampson (actor)|Robert Sampson]] | country = United States | language = English | executive_producer = [[Douglas S. Cramer]] | producer = Jerry London (pilot)
Don Nelson
Arthur Alsberg | company = The Douglas S. Cramer Company
Thornhill Productions
[[Screen Gems]] | distributor = [[Sony Pictures Television]] | theme_music_composer = [[Jerry Fielding]]
Diane Hildebrand | composer = Jerry Fielding | network = [[CBS]] | opentheme = "Love Is Crazy" | camera = | first_aired = {{Start date|1972|9|16}} | last_aired = {{End date|1973|3|3}} | num_episodes = 24 | num_seasons = 1 | website = }} '''''Bridget Loves Bernie''''' is an American [[sitcom]] created by [[Bernard Slade]]. Depicting an interfaith marriage between a Catholic woman and a Jewish man, ''Bridget Loves Bernie'' was based loosely on the premise of the 1920s Broadway play and 1940s radio show ''[[Abie's Irish Rose]]''. It stars [[Meredith Baxter]] and [[David Birney]] as the title characters. It was canceled by [[CBS]] after only one season, despite high ratings. Baxter and Birney married in real life after the program went off the air. ==Overview== [[File:Robert Sampson Bridget Loves Bernie 1972.JPG|thumb|150px|Father Mike picking up the Archbishop's weekly bagel supply.]] The series depicted an interfaith marriage between an [[Irish Catholic]] teacher (Bridget) from a wealthy family and a [[Jews|Jewish]] cab driver (Bernie), whom she had met at a bus stop. With a primetime slot between ''[[All in the Family]]'' and ''[[The Mary Tyler Moore Show]]'' on Saturday nights, the situation comedy was #5 in the ratings among all shows for the 1972-73 television season and obtained a 24.2 rating, tying with ''[[The NBC Mystery Movie|The NBC Sunday Mystery Movie]].'' However, CBS executives canceled the show in response to negative reactions to the characters' marriage, making it the highest-rated television program to be canceled after only one season.[https://www.washingtonpost.com/ac2/wp-dyn/A21263-2002Dec6 "'Live From Baghdad': The Cameras of War"], by Tom Shales, ''[[Washington Post]]'', December 7, 2002, citing ''[[Brilliant But Canceled]]'' documentary on [[Trio (TV network)]] cable network. Retrieved 2007-11-12.{{dead link|date=December 2015}} Supporting cast members included [[Audra Lindley]], [[David Doyle (actor)|David Doyle]], [[Harold J. Stone]], [[Ned Glass]], and [[Bibi Osterwald]]. Lindley and Doyle played Bridget's wealthy parents, Walter and Amy Fitzgerald, and Stone and Osterwald played Bernie's working class parents, Sam and Sophie Steinberg. The Steinbergs owned a delicatessen above which Bridget and Bernie lived. Glass played Bernie's uncle, Moe Plotnik. Actor Robert Sampson played Bridget's brother, Catholic priest Father Michael Fitzgerald; he was more sympathetic than others to his sister's marriage. Bill Elliott played Otis, Bernie's best friend and fellow cab driver. [[Nora Marlowe]] was cast as Aunt Agnes in the 1972 episode "The Little White Lie That Grew and Grew". ==Cast== *[[David Birney]] as Bernie Steinberg *[[Bibi Osterwald]] as Sophie Steinberg *[[Meredith Baxter]] as Bridget Fitzgerald Steinberg *[[Harold J. Stone]] as Sam Steinberg *[[Audra Lindley]] as Amy Fitzgerald *[[David Doyle (actor)|David Doyle]] as Walter Fitzgerald *[[Ned Glass]] as Moe Plotnik *Robert Sampson as Father Michael Fitzgerald *Bill Elliott as Otis Foster == Controversy over content == The series was controversial due to the differing faiths of the married characters. Some Jewish groups charged that the series "mocked the teachings of Judaism.""'Bridget Loves Bernie' Attacked by Jewish Groups' The New York Times, Feb 7, 1973"Some Jews Are Mad At Bernie; Intermarriage Religion, New York Times, Feb 11, 1973 Rabbi [[Wolfe Kelman]], executive vice-president of the [[Rabbinical Assembly]] of America, called the show “an insult to some of the most sacred values of both the Jewish and Catholic religions."[http://www.jta.org/1972/10/24/archive/jewish-groups-score-new-tv-show-for-intermarriage-theme Jewish Groups Score New Tv Show for Intermarriage Theme] The Jewish Daily Forward, Oct 24, 1972 [[Rabbi Meir Kahane]] dedicated full columns to the episode.{{cite web|last1=Kahane|first1=Meir|title=What Makes Bernie Run?|url=http://mkwords.com/text/index.php?i=60&a=What%20Makes%20Bernie%20Run?|website=mkwords.com|location=Manhattan, NY|date=1975}} [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox rabbis]] met with CBS officials several times. A [[Conservative Judaism|conservative rabbi]] organized a boycott by advertisers, and [[Reform Judaism|reform rabbis]] met with CBS staff in secret to have the show cancelled. Rabbi [[Abraham Gross]], president of the Rabbinical Alliance of Orthodox Rabbis and Educators, described the show as a "flagrant insult" to Jews, protesting that intermarriage was strictly forbidden under Jewish law. Threats followed. Meredith Baxter said, "We had bomb threats on the show. Some guys from the [[Jewish Defense League]] came to my house to say they wanted to talk with me about changing the show." Threatening phone calls made to the home of producer [[Ralph Riskin]] resulted in the arrest of Robert S. Manning,"Producer Gets Threat Call, Milwaukee Sentinel, January 19, 1973 described as a member of the [[Jewish Defense League]]."David Zurawik, The Jews of Prime Time, Brandeis Series in American Jewish History, Culture, and Life, 2003, p. 94 Manning was later indicted on murder charges, and fought extradition to the U.S. from Israel, where he had moved.[Murder Suspect Overdoses, Delaying Extradition to U.S. LA Times, July 14, 1993] ==Episodes== {| class=wikitable style="background:#FFFFFF" ! style="background:#FFD700; width:20px"| Nº ! style="background:#FFD700"| Title ! style="background:#FFD700"| Directed by ! style="background:#FFD700"| Written by ! style="background:#FFD700; width:135px"| Air date {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 1 | Title = Bridget Loves Bernie | DirectedBy = [[Richard Kinon]] | WrittenBy = [[Bernard Slade]] | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1972|9|16}} | ShortSummary = [[Pilot episode|Series pilot]]: It's love at first sight when cab driver (and struggling writer) Bernie Steinberg picks up his fare, Bridget Fitzgerald, on a rainy New York day. | LineColor = FFD700 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 2 | Title = A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Vatican | DirectedBy = [[Lee Philips]] | WrittenBy = [[John McGreevey]] | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1972|9|23}} | ShortSummary = Bernie's parents, Sam and Sophie, win a raffle ticket for a private audience with [[Pope Paul VI]] that was sold by Bridget's mother, Amy. Her father, Walt, fears that the Steinbergs may end up causing him major embarrassment. | LineColor = FFD700 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 3 | Title = Wake Up, We're Getting Married Today | DirectedBy = Richard Kinon | WrittenBy = Don Nelson and Arthur Alsberg | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1972|9|30}} | ShortSummary = After being married in a civil ceremony, Bridget and Bernie agree to their parents' wishes to have a religious ceremony, but the conflict of religions causes havoc. | LineColor = FFD700 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 4 | Title = The Last of the Red Hot Playwrights | DirectedBy = Richard Kinon | WrittenBy = Bernard Slade | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1972|10|7}} | ShortSummary = Despite several rejections, a reluctant Bernie decides to write a play drawn from his own experiences and personal acquaintances. | LineColor = FFD700 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 5 | Title = Who's Watching the Store? | DirectedBy = Lee Philips | WrittenBy = Jerry Mayer | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1972|10|14}} | ShortSummary = Confusion and chaos reign when Catholic Bridget runs a Jewish delicatessen, aided by her socialite mother and brother who's a priest. | LineColor = FFD700 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 6 | Title = The Newlybeds | DirectedBy = Richard Kinon | WrittenBy = Warren S. Murray | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1972|10|21}} | ShortSummary = Trying to replace a perennially-breaking bed results not only in sleeping trouble for Bridget and Bernie, but also causes an inter-family squabble. | LineColor = FFD700 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 7 | Title = Happiness Is Just a Thing Called Moe | DirectedBy = [[Hal Cooper (director)|Hal Cooper]] | WrittenBy = Lloyd FFD700 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 8 | Title = Bernie's Last Stand | DirectedBy = Richard Kinon | WrittenBy = Burt and Adele Styler | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1972|11|4}} | ShortSummary = Despite a generous (and belated) wedding gift of one year's free rent on a plush apartment from Walt and Amy, she and Bernie are reluctant to accept the offer. | LineColor = FFD700 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 9 | Title = How to Be a Jewish Mother | DirectedBy = Richard Kinon | WrittenBy = George Burditt and Paul Wayne | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1972|11|11}} | ShortSummary = After Bernie rejects Bridget's breakfast of ham and eggs, she decides to take a crash course in Jewish cooking, which leads to disaster. | LineColor = FFD700 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 10 | Title = The Little White Lie That Grew and Grew | DirectedBy = Don Nelson and Arthur Alsberg | WrittenBy = Lee Philips | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1972|11|18}} | ShortSummary = Bridget and her parents become Jewish for the weekend when Bernie's devout aunt stops in New York on her way back from Israel. | LineColor = FFD700 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 11 | Title = The In-Laws Who Came to collector will be compromised when the in-laws move in after smoke damage currently has their apartment under repair. | LineColor = FFD700 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 12 | Title = The Homecoming | DirectedBy = [[Ezra Stone]] | WrittenBy = Bernard Slade | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1972|12|2}} | ShortSummary = Bridget and Bernie spend the weekend at the Fitzgerald country estate and after Bernie meets some of Bridget's friends, he becomes aware of the style to which she was previously accustomed. | LineColor = FFD700 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 13 | Title = You Are holding for United Nations delegates. However, his mother is determined to attend after discovering [[Moshe Dayan]] will be the guest of honor. | LineColor = FFD700 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 14 | Title = 'Tis the Season | whether to celebrate Christmas or Hanukkah. | LineColor = FFD700 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 15 | Title = Belated Honeymoon | DirectedBy = Coby Ruskin | WrittenBy = Joanna Lee | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1972|12|23}} | ShortSummary = Increasing tensions between Bridget and Bernie lead both sets of parents to send them on the honeymoon they never had. | LineColor = FFD700 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 16 | Title = Honesty Is the Worst Policy | DirectedBy = Richard Kinon | WrittenBy = Howard Merrill | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1973|1|6}} | ShortSummary = away from home after Sam and Sophie decide he should retire from the deli. | LineColor = FFD700 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 18 | Title = With This Ring | DirectedBy = [[Ozzie Nelson]] | WrittenBy = Gordon Farr and Arnold Kane | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1973|1|20}} | ShortSummary = Bernie is finally able to buy Bridget an engagement ring, but she quickly loses it. | LineColor = FFD700 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 19 | Title = Into Every Life, a Little Snow Must Fall | DirectedBy = James Sheldon | WrittenBy = Elias Davis | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1973|1|27}} | ShortSummary = Bridget and Bernie talk their fathers into spending a weekend at Walt's hunting lodge. | LineColor = FFD700 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 20 | Title = To Teach or Not to Teach | DirectedBy = James Sheldon | WrittenBy = Don Nelson and Arthur Alsberg | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1973|2|3}} | ShortSummary = Bridget announces that she's going to teach a sex education class to her fourth graders. | LineColor = FFD700 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 21 | Title = Painting, Painting – Who's Got the Painting? | DirectedBy = Ozzie Nelson | WrittenBy = [[Bill Dana]] | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1973|2|10}} | ShortSummary = Bridget has a hard time finding a home for a painting that once hung in her nursery until she discovers a potentially rare painting is found hidden under the surface of the canvas. | LineColor = FFD700 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 22 | Title = Steinberg and Son | DirectedBy = Richard Kinon | WrittenBy = Jerry Mayer | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1973|2|17}} | ShortSummary = Sam and Walt each get the chance to realize their dream of having Bernie work for them. | LineColor = FFD700 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 23 | Title = The Information Gap | DirectedBy = Ozzie Nelson | WrittenBy = Marty Roth | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1973|2|24}} | ShortSummary = In an effort to get some measure of privacy, Bridget and Bernie decide to ignore all questions and phone calls from their parents. | LineColor = FFD700 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 24 | Title = Greener Pastures | DirectedBy = [[Bill Bixby]] | WrittenBy = Rick Mittleman | OriginalAirDate = {{start date|1973|3|3}} | ShortSummary = Bernie is offered the opportunity to work for a newspaper in Providence. | LineColor = FFD700 }} |} ==Home media== On December 4, 2012, [[Sony Pictures Home Entertainment]] released the complete series on [[DVD]] in Region 1.{{cite web |url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Bridget-Loves-Bernie-The-Complete-Series/17826 |title=Bridget Loves Bernie DVD news: Update about Bridget Loves Bernie - The Complete Series Manufacture-on-Demand (MOD) release, available exclusively through [[Amazon.com]] and WBShop.com and only in the US. == References == {{reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category|Bridget Loves revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Bruce Almighty | image = BruceAlmighty poster.jpg | image_size = 200px | alt = A man with the world attached to his finger by a piece of rosary | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Tom Shadyac]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * Tom Shadyac * [[Jim Carrey]]{{cite web|url=http://www.jimcarreyonline.com/info/faqs.html?answer=21|title=Frequently Asked Questions|work=Jim Carrey Online|accessdate=February 18, 2009}} * [[James D. Brubaker]] * Michael Bostick * [[Steve Koren]] * [[Mark O'Keefe (screenwriter)|Mark O'Keefe]] }} | screenplay = {{Plainlist| * Steve Koren * Mark O'Keefe * [[Steve Oedekerk]]}} | story = {{Plainlist| * Steve Koren * Mark O'Keefe }} | starring = {{Plainlist| * Jim Carrey * [[Morgan Freeman]] * [[Jennifer Aniston]] * [[Philip Baker Hall]] * [[Lisa Ann Walter]] * [[Catherine Bell (actress)|Catherine Bell]] * [[Steve Carell]] }} | music = [[John Debney]] | cinematography = [[Dean Semler]] | editing = Scott Hill | studio = {{Plainlist| * [[Spyglass Entertainment]] * [[Shady Acres Entertainment|Shady Acres]] * Pit Bull Productions }} | distributor = [[Universal Pictures]] (US)
[[Buena Vista Pictures|Buena Vista International]] (International) {{cite web|url= https://www.screendaily.com/bvi-hits-milestones-with-pirates-bruce-almighty/4015393.article|title= BVI hits milestones with Pirates, Bruce Almighty|work=ScreenDaily|accessdate=January 12, 2018}}{{cite web|url= https://variety.com/2003/film/box-office/bvi-goes-over-the-top-o-seas-1117894216/|title= BVI goes over the top o'seas|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=January 12, 2018}} | released = {{Film date|2003|5|14|[[Hollywood]]|2003|05|23|United States}} | runtime = 101 minutes{{cite web|title=''BRUCE ALMIGHTY'' (12A)|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/AFF182526/|work=[[British Board of Film Classification]]|date=2003-05-22|accessdate=2012-01-13}} | country = United States | language = English | budget = $81 million | gross = $484.6 million{{cite web | title = Bruce Almighty (2003)|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=brucealmighty.htm |work=[[Box Office Mojo]]| publisher= Amazon.com}} }} '''''Bruce Almighty''''' is a 2003 American [[fantasy film|fantasy]] [[comedy film]] directed by [[Tom Shadyac]] and written by [[Steve Koren]], Mark O'Keefe and [[Steve Oedekerk]]. It stars [[Jim Carrey]] as Bruce Nolan, a down-on-his-luck TV reporter who complains to [[God]] ([[Morgan Freeman]]) that he is not doing his job correctly, and is offered the chance to try being God himself for one week. It is Shadyac and Carrey's third collaboration, having previously worked together on ''[[Ace Ventura: Pet Detective]]'' in 1994 and ''[[Liar Liar]]'' in 1997. It co-stars [[Jennifer Aniston]], [[Lisa Ann Walter]], [[Philip Baker Hall]] and [[Steve Carell]], and received mixed reviews from critics. When released in American theaters in May 2003 it opened to $85.9 million, making it the best [[Memorial Day]] opening weekend of any film in history at the time.{{cite web|title=''Bruce'' Blesses Memorial Weekend with $85.73 Million |url= http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=1246&p=.htm}} The film surprised film pundits when it beat ''[[The Matrix Reloaded]]'' the following weekend. By the end of its theatrical run, it made $242 million domestically and a total $484 million worldwide, making it the [[2003 in film#Highest-grossing films|fifth highest-grossing film of 2003]]. ''[[Evan Almighty]]'', a [[spin-off (media)|spin-off]] [[sequel]] focusing on Carell's character, with Shadyac and Oedekerk returning to direct and write, and Freeman also reprising his role, was released in 2007. ==Plot== Bruce Nolan ([[Jim Carrey]]) is a television field reporter for [[Eyewitness News]] at [[WKBW-TV]] in [[Buffalo, New York]], but desires to be the news anchorman instead. Bruce is in a relationship with his girlfriend, Grace Connelly ([[Jennifer Aniston]]), but he also has a mild crush on his co-worker, Susan Ortega ([[Catherine Bell (actress)|Catherine Bell]]). However, Bruce suffers from constant bad luck and reaches his breaking point when he is passed over for promotion by his rival, Evan Baxter ([[Steve Carell]]), who later steals dialogue from an unaired segment by Bruce while accepting the promotion on air. This causes Bruce himself to aggressively and insanely criticize the station during his first live report, and he is promptly fired. Following a series of other misfortunes (getting beaten up by a group of street thugs who vandalize his car, and later plowing his car into a street post), Bruce takes out his frustration on [[God in Christianity|God]], blaming Him and claiming that He is "the one who should be fired." Bruce later receives a message on his pager directing him to an empty warehouse, where he meets God ([[Morgan Freeman]]). God offers to give Bruce His job to see if Bruce can do a better job. God gives Bruce two rules that he must follow: Bruce cannot tell anyone else that he is God, and Bruce cannot use his powers to interfere with [[free will]]. Initially, Bruce becomes jubilant with the powers, using them for personal gain such as getting revenge on the street gang that assaulted him earlier, transforming his clothes and his damaged car into a [[Saleen S7]]{{cite web|title=Motor Trend: "Bruce Almighty" Saleen S7 on eBay|url=http://www.motortrend.com/news/112_news030815_s7/|website=Motor Trend|date=15 August 2003}} and sexually impressing Grace. Bruce also finds ways of using the powers to cause miraculous events to occur at otherwise mundane events that he covers, such as discovering the body of [[Jimmy Hoffa]], earning him his job back, and causing a meteor to harmlessly land near a Mark Twain-themed chili cook-off. Bruce, still wanting the anchor position as well as wanting to get revenge on Evan Baxter for taunting him, uses his powers to make Evan humiliate himself on air, causing Evan to be replaced in favor of Bruce as the new anchor. After taking Grace to a fancy dinner and telling her about his promotion (disappointing her, as she thought he was going to propose), Bruce begins to hear voices in his head. He re-encounters God, who explains that the voices are prayers to God, and that Bruce must deal with them. Bruce creates an e-mail system to receive prayers and respond to them - but finds that the influx is far too great for him to handle, even with the use of his powers. So he sets the program to automatically answer "Yes" to every prayer, thinking this will make everyone happy. During a party to celebrate Bruce's promotion, Susan seduces and kisses him. When Grace arrives and sees this, she angrily storms out; Bruce follows her, but she is heartbroken and won't listen to him. He tries to use his powers to convince Grace to stay, but cannot influence her free will. As Bruce looks around, he realizes that automatically granting everyone's prayers has plunged the city into chaos. Bruce returns to God, who explains that despite how chaotic things seem, there is always a way to make things right, and that Bruce must figure out a way to solve it himself. Bruce then begins to solve his problems in life practically, such as helping a man whose car has broken down, potty training his dog properly, and allowing Evan to have his job back. Bruce returns to his computer system, having briefly unplugged it, and he finds many prayers from Grace about Bruce. As he reads them, another prayer from Grace arrives, this one wishing not to be in love with Bruce anymore. A despondent Bruce walks alone on a highway, asking God to take back His powers and letting his fate be in His hands. Bruce is suddenly struck by a truck and regains consciousness in a white void. God appears and tells Bruce to pray for what he truly wants; Bruce prays for Grace to find a man that would make her happy. God agrees and Bruce finds himself in the hospital, shortly after being miraculously revived by the doctors. Grace arrives and the two reconcile. After his recovery, Bruce returns to his field of reporting, but takes more pleasure in simple stories. Bruce and Grace announce their engagement on live television during a 'Be the Miracle' blood drive. The film ends with a homeless man holding a sign with philosophical messages that Bruce previously ran into on various occasions finally revealing himself to be God. ==Cast== {{Div col}} * [[Jim Carrey]] as Bruce Nolan * [[Morgan Freeman]] as [[God in Christianity|God]] * [[Jennifer Aniston]] as Grace Connelly * [[Lisa Ann Walter]] as Debbie Connelly * [[Philip Baker Hall]] as Jack Baylor * [[Steve Carell]] as Evan Baxter * [[Catherine Bell (actress)|Catherine Bell]] as Susan Ortega * [[Sally Kirkland]] as Anita Mann * [[Nora Dunn]] as Ally Loman * [[Eddie Jemison]] as Bobby * [[Micah Stephen Williams]] as boy on bike * [[Tony Bennett]] as himself * [[Carlos Sánchez (Colombian actor)|Carlos Sánchez]] as [[Juan Valdez]] * [[John Murphy (sportscaster)|John Murphy]] as himself * Madeline Lovejoy as Zoe * [[Noel Gugliemi]] as hood {{div col end}} ==Reception== ''Bruce Almighty'' received mixed reviews from critics. The film has a score of 49% on [[Rotten Tomatoes]], based on 188 reviews, with an average rating of 5.7/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "Carrey is hilarious in the slapstick scenes, but ''Bruce Almighty'' gets bogged down in treacle".[http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/bruce_almighty/ Rotten Tomatoes on Bruce Almighty] The film also has a score of 46 out of 100 on [[Metacritic]], based on 35 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".[http://www.metacritic.com/movie/bruce-almighty Metacritic on Bruce Almighty] The film was released in the [[United Kingdom]] on June 27, 2003, and topped the country's box office that weekend.{{cite web|url=http://www.25thframe.co.uk/charts/chart.php?chart=20030711|title=Weekend box office 27th June 2003 - 29th June 2003|publisher=www.25thframe.co.uk|accessdate=9 March 2017}} ===Controversy=== The film was banned in [[Egypt]], due to the portrayal of God as a visually ordinary man. Bans in both Malaysia and Egypt were eventually lifted after the censorship boards in respective countries gave it the highest rating, (18-PL in the case of Malaysia).{{cite web|url=http://www.middle-east-online.com/english/?id=7703 |title=Middle East Online}}{{cite web |url=http://www.kuwaittimes.net/read_news.php?newsid=NTEyMjkzNTUx |title=Malaysian Muslims call for ban on movie, AFP, Fri July 13, 2007 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081207031318/http://www.kuwaittimes.net/read_news.php?newsid=NTEyMjkzNTUx |archivedate=December 7, 2008 |df= }} Since God contacts Bruce using an actual phone number rather than a number in the standard fictional [[555 (telephone number)|555]] [[telephone exchange]], several people and groups sharing this number subsequently received hundreds of phone calls from people wanting to talk to God, including a church in [[North Carolina]] (where the Minister was named Bruce), a Pastor in Northern Wisconsin and a man in [[Manchester]], [[England]].http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2011-03-29/entertainment/sc-mov-0330-movie-phone-numbers-20110329_1_number-customer-service-representative-dial The producers noted that the number (776-2323) was not in use in the area code ([[Area code 716|716]], which was never specified on screen) in the film's story but did not check anywhere else. The home video and television versions changed it to the fictional 555-0123.http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/manchester/3033576.stm ===Spin-off/sequel=== A [[Sequel#Stand-alone sequels|spin-off/sequel]], titled ''[[Evan Almighty]]'', was released on June 22, 2007, with [[Steve Carell]] reprising his role as Evan Baxter and [[Morgan Freeman]] returning to his role as [[God]]. Although Shadyac returned to direct the sequel, neither Carrey nor Aniston were involved with the film, and Carrey's character, Bruce, is never mentioned in the film. The sequel was not as well received as its predecessor, with a 23% rating on [[Rotten Tomatoes]] and a 37/100 score on [[Metacritic]]. == Awards and Nominations == {| class="wikitable" !Association !Category !Nominee !Results |- |[[American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers|ASCAP Film and Television Music award]] |Top Box Office Films |John Debney |{{WON}} |- |ASCAP Film and Television Music award |Most Performed Song from a Motion Picture "I'm With You" |Graham Edwards Avril Lavigne |{{WON}} |- |BET Comedy award |Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Box Office Movie |Morgan Freeman |{{Nominated}} |- |[[Black Reel Awards|Black Reel award]] |[[Black Reel Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor|Film: Best Supporting Actor]] |Morgan Freeman |{{Nominated}} |- |[[JoBlo.com|Golden Schmoes award]] |Most Overrated Movie of the Year |N/A |{{Nominated}} |- |[[NAACP Image Awards|Image award]] |[[Image Awards 2004|Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Motion Picture]] |Morgan Freeman |{{WON}} |- |[[MTV Movie & TV Awards|MTV Movie + TV award]] |[[MTV Movie Award for Best Comedic Performance|Best Comedic Performance]] |Jim Carrey |{{Nominated}} |- |MTV Movie + TV award |[[MTV Movie Award for Best Kiss|Best Kiss]] |Jim Carrey Jennifer Aniston |{{Nominated}} |- |[[MTV Movie Awards Mexico 2004|MTV Movie award, Mexico]] |[[MTV Movie Awards Mexico 2004|Most Divine Miracle in a Movie (for the chest of Grace)]] |Jim Carrey |{{WON}} |- |[[Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Awards|Nickelodeon Kid's Choice award]] |Favorite Movie |N/A |{{Nominated}} |- |Nickelodeon Kid's Choice award |Favorite Movie Actor |Jim Carrey |{{WON}} |- |[[People's Choice Awards|People's Choice award]] |Favorite Comedy Motion Picture |N/A |{{WON}} |- |[[Teen Choice Awards|Teen Choice award]] |[[Teen Choice Award for Choice Movie Actor – Comedy|Choice Movie Actor - Comedy]] |Jim Carrey |{{WON}} |- |Teen Choice award |[[Teen Choice Award for Choice Movie Actress – Comedy|Choice Movie Actress - Comedy]] |Jennifer Aniston |{{Nominated}} |- |Teen Choice award |Choice Movie - Chemistry |Jim Carrey Morgan Freeman |{{Nominated}} |} ==Soundtrack== {{Infobox album | name = Bruce Almighty: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack | type = soundtrack | artist = [[John Debney]], Various Artists | cover = | alt = | released = June 3, 2003 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = Soundtrack | length = | label = [[Varèse Sarabande]] | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} {{Album ratings | rev1 = [[AllMusic]] | rev1Score = {{Rating|3|5}} {{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r643556|pure_url=yes}}|title=Review: ''Bruce Almighty: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack''|last=Phares|first=Heather|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=30 August 2009}} }} The soundtrack was released on June 3, 2003 by [[Varèse Sarabande]]. Tracks 8-13 are from the score composed by [[John Debney]], performed by the [[Hollywood Studio Symphony]] (conducted by Pete Anthony) with Brad Dechter and Sandy De Crescent. ;Track listing # "[[One of Us (Joan Osborne song)|One of Us]]" - [[Joan Osborne]] # "God Shaped Hole" - [[Plumb (singer)|Plumb]] # "[[You're a God]]" - [[Vertical Horizon]] # "[[The Power (Snap! song)|The Power]]" - [[Snap!]] # "[[A Little Less Conversation]]" - [[Elvis Presley|Elvis]] vs. [[Junkie XL|JXL]] # "[[The Rockafeller Skank]]" - [[Norman Cook|Fatboy Slim]] # "[[Goddess in the Doorway|God Gave Me Everything]]" - [[Mick Jagger]] featuring [[Lenny Kravitz]] # "AB Positive" # "Walking on Water" # "Bruce Meets God" # "Bruce's Prayer" # "Grace's Prayer" # "Seventh at Seven" ==Adaptations== *''[[God Tussi Great Ho]]'' *''[[Evan Almighty]],'' a follow-up film starring [[Steve Carell]] instead of Carrey ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote}} * {{Official website|http://www.brucealmighty.com/}} * {{IMDb title|0315327|Bruce Almighty}} * {{allrovi movie|278865|Bruce Almighty}} * {{mojo title|brucealmighty|Bruce Almighty}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|bruce_almighty|Bruce Almighty}} * {{metacritic film|bruce-almighty|Bruce Almighty}} {{Tom Shadyac}} {{Jim Carrey}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bruce Almighty}} [[Category:2003 films]] [[Category:2000s comedy films]] [[Category:2000s drama films]] [[Category:2000s fantasy films]] [[Category:2000s romance films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American comedy-drama films]] [[Category:American fantasy-comedy films]] [[Category:American romantic comedy films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Tom Shadyac]] [[Category:Buffalo, New York in fiction]] [[Category:God in fiction]] [[Category:Films about television]] [[Category:Films set in New York (state)]] [[Category:Religious comedy films]] [[Category:Spyglass Entertainment films]] [[Category:Universal Pictures films]] [[Category:Films scored by John Debney]] [[Category:Films about wish fulfillment]] [[Category:Screenplays by Steve Oedekerk]]

revision.text:
{{one source|date=May 2013}} '''Chen''' is the Chinese term for '[[prophecy]]'.<ref>Zongli Lü 2003, p. 20</ref> It is also written ''chan''<ref>Zongli Lü 2003, p. 13</ref> or, in the [[Wade–Giles]] transliteration as "''ch'an''":<ref>Charles Alexander Moore : ''The Chinese Mind''. University of Hawaii Press, 1967. p. 113</ref> "The ''Ch'an'', couched in enigmatic language, predicted luck and disaster, and constituted [[oracle]] books."<ref>[http://www2.iath.virginia.edu/saxon/servlet/SaxonServlet?source=xwomen/texts/bohu.xml&style=xwomen/xsl/dynaxml.xsl&chunk.id=d2.2&toc.id=d2.2&doc.lang=bilingual''Po Hu T'ung'' (Discussions at White Tiger Pavilion), "Introduction", section 32]</ref> These prophecies could derive from a dream,<ref>Zongli Lü 2003, p. 16</ref> be brought from overseas,<ref>Zongli Lü2003, p. 18</ref> be discovered in excavated inscriptions,<ref>Zongli Lü 2003, p. 19</ref> or be revealed in "an ecstatic trance".<ref>Zongli Lü 2003, p. 299</ref> These prophetic texts were much used by the emperors.
==Chen and the emperors== At the partition of the empire at the end of the [[Eastern Han Dynasty|Later Han Dynasty]], "[[Liu Bei]] ... (161–223) in [[Shu Han|Shu]] and [[Sun Quan]] ... (182–252) in [[Eastern Wu|Wu]] proclaimed their own mandates and, of course, used favorable ''chen'' prophecies ... to serve their own purposes."<ref>Zongli Lü 2003, p. 39</ref> In the [[Liang Dynasty]], "[[Emperor Wu of Liang|Emperor Wu]] himself quoted prophetic-apocryphal texts".<ref>Zongli Lü 2003, p. 57</ref> In the [[Sui Dynasty]], ''chen'' texts were promoted by Wang Shao (''fl''. 543–608) : as "imperial historian, Wang repeatedly presented favorable prophetic-apocryphal texts and contemporary ''chen'' prophecies to [[Emperor Wen of Sui|Emperor Wen]] ... . The emperor was greatly pleased. Encouraged, Wang collected ... ''chen'' prophecies ... and ''wei'' apocryphal texts, and compiled a ... collection ... . Emperor Wen then had this collection distributed nationwide.<ref>Zongli Lü 2003, p. 68</ref> As founder of the Sui Dynasty, "When [[Sui Dynasty#Emperor Yang of Sui|Yang]] first enthroned himself, ... he declared that there had been a large number of ... ''chen'' prophecies in his favor.".<ref>Zongli Lü 2003, p. 101</ref>
===Chen as description=== These prophetic texts were also officially accepted as descriptions of particular emperors. An official description of [[Emperor Gao of Southern Qi|Emperor Gao]] of the [[Southern Qi Dynasty]] stated that "His Majesty's name, physical characteristics, as well as the tide, destiny, and the order of succession all correspond with dozens to nearly one hundred ''chen'' prophecies."<ref>Zongli Lü 2003, p. 89</ref>
==Other prophetic texts== Other instances of such prophecy are the ''Wan Nian Ke'' ("10,000 Years' Poem")<ref>[http://www.pureinsight.org/node/4440 Pure Insight: Tentative Interpretation of the Last Part of "Universe 10K Years Prophecy Poem"]</ref> by [[Jiang Ziya]], composed early in the [[Western Zhou dynasty]]; and the ''Cang Tou'' ("Secret Record")<ref>[http://www.pureinsight.org/node/4480 Pure Insight: The Great Chinese Prophecies (20)]</ref> by [[Li Chunfeng]], composed during the [[Tang dynasty]].
== Notes == {{reflist}}
==Work cited== *Zongli Lü, ''Power of The Words : Chen Prophecy in Chinese Politics, AD 265–618'', Peter Lang (2003) {{ISBN|0-8204-5868-6}}
==External links== *[http://texts.00.gs/Power_of_the_Words.htm Page from Ch'en Prophecy in Chinese Politics AD 265–618]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Chen Prophecy}} [[Category:Religion in China]]
